text: The inflammatory response is a double-edged sword .
Properly orchestrated , it results in the clearing of foreign molecules and invading pathogens from the body .
Uncontrolled , it may lead to organ damage , sepsis , and even cancer [ 1 ] - [ 3 ] .

Many of the pathological manifestations of the inflammatory response are mediated by cytokines and other inducible gene products expressed by macrophages upon exposure to the gram - negative bacterial cell wall component LPS .

As macrophages are key effectors of pathogen - induced innate immune responses , their survival is critical for initial pathogen neutralization and subsequent development of adaptive immune responses .

One of the most LPS - inducible macrophage gene products known is the ovalbumin-like serine protease inhibitor ( ov-serpin ) <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a widely recognized macrophage survival factor [ 4 ] ; [ 5 ] .

<extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was first identified as an inhibitor of <extra_id_0> urokinase-type plasminogen activator <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> uPA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) [ 6 ] - [ 8 ] , a serine protease involved in the degradation and turnover of the extracellular matrix through the activation of <extra_id_0> plasminogen <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 7 ] ; [ 9 ] .

Such function requires <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to be secreted from the cell yet <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> exists primarily as a nonglycosylated intracellular protein [ 10 ] .

Over the past decade , intracellular roles for <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in cell survival [ 11 ] - [ 17 ] , proliferation and differentiation [ 18 ] - [ 21 ] , signal transduction [ 15 ] ; [ 22 ] ; [ 23 ] and innate immunity [ 24 ] - [ 28 ] , have been described .
The <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene is highly regulated in a cell type specific manner analogous to that of cytokines and oncogenes [ 29 ] ; [ 30 ] .
It is one of the most responsive genes known [ 31 ] , and can be induced over 1000-fold by LPS [ 31 ] - [ 32 ] , and is up-regulated by a range of inflammatory mediators [ 9 ] .
LPS activates immune responses through multiple signalling pathways .

The <extra_id_0> toll-like receptor 4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TLR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is responsible for the recognition of LPS and other microbial products and plays a central role in the initiation of innate immune responses , including cytokine release .

The binding of LPS to <extra_id_0> TLR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on the surface of macrophages leads to the recruitment of adaptor molecules and the activation of protein kinases , generating signals to the nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) , mitogen - activated protein kinase ( MAPK ) and / or phosphoinositide 3 ( PI3 ) - kinase pathways [ 33 ] .

In studies aimed at identifying LPS - inducible pro-survival factors downstream of p38 MAPK , <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was identified as a factor whose expression was upregulated by cooperation of the <extra_id_0> IKKbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / NF-kappaB and p38 MAPK / CREB pathways [ 16 ] .

Our previously published data indicated that <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is distinctly regulated from other LPS - inducible genes in terms of kinetics , LPS dose response and sensitivity to <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> co - stimulation [ 4 ] ; however , the cis - acting elements in the <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter responsible for LPS - dependent transcription in macrophages and the specific LPS - responsive transcription factors that bind the <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter were not defined .

Here we show that LPS induction of <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is dependent upon cis - acting regulatory sequences in the region between nucleotides -189 and -539 of the murine <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter , and is critically dependent upon a C / EBP binding site at -203 / -195 .

<extra_id_0> C/EBP-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> directly bound to this site in vivo and its deficiency abrogated constitutive <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction by LPS .

Importantly , a <extra_id_0> C/EBP-beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phospho - acceptor site was found to negatively regulate LPS - induced <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter activity .
Together , these findings provide new insight into the transcriptional regulation of the <extra_id_0> SerpinB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .
